item.title: #1017 split-join as part of 7-zip cmdline for small filesystems
item.detail: splitting and joining of volumes should be part of 7-zip commandline parameters. it should be part of 7-zip as a whole. what I mean is, it should be able to archive while splitting into bite-size chunks of n size. n should be a 64-bit number. the purpose of this feature is to make provisions for filesystems such as FAT32 and FAT16, which people still use, and must put archive files on, but the filesystem cannot handle more than 4GiB per file. or floppies which can only handle 1440KB, or DVD's which can only handle 4700MB. or cd's which can only handle 737MB, and then there's blu-ray, DL-DVDR... the problem comes when you have an 18+GB archive. you are now in the position that you can't join them in order to unzip them. ouch. what you need is the kind of 7-zip which can unzip a volume in pieces without joining. sequentially numbered chunks. and don't think 2 digits are going to suffice. this is probably going to require a partial rewrite of the compression and decompression engine. but it will make 7-zip FAR more useful, maybe even as a backup tool on unix systems and windows systems! (look - new feature/bullet point for the web page) this is nothing like the existing split tool in 7-zip GUI - it has no smarts. I have written an very enhanced atoi64 which could be of use for this which handles hexadecimal, octal, binary, and decimal (different number types), and also handles computer-size measurements and SI measurements as suffixes _B, _KB, _MB, _GB, _TB, _PB, _EB, _KiB, _MiB, _GiB, _TiB, _PiB, _EiB. it works quite well except that it returns 0 on error, like atoi64. I am attaching it. I hope you will find it useful enough to use throughout 7-zip for inputting numbers.

item.title: #445 generate archive name using the current date and time
item.detail: Switch -AG[format] - generate archive name using the current date and time like WinRAR archiver. Appends the current date string to an archive name when creating an archive. Useful for daily backups. Format of the appending string is defined by the optional format parameter or by "YYYYMMDDHHMMSS" if this parameter is absent. The format string may include the following characters: Y year M month MMM month as text string (Jan, Feb, etc.) W a week number (a week starts with Monday) A day of week (Monday is 1, Sunday is 7) D day of month E day of year H hours M minutes (treated as minutes if encountered after hours) S seconds N archive number. WinRAR searches for already existing archive with generated name and if found, increments the archive number until generating a unique name. Each of format string characters listed above represents only one character added to archive name. For example, use WW for two digit week number or YYYY to define the four digit year. If the first character in the format string is '+', positions of the date string and base archive name are exchanged, so a date will precede an archive name. The format string may contain optional text enclosed in '{' and '}' characters. This text is inserted into archive name. All other characters are added to an archive name without changes. If you need to update an already existing archive, be careful with -ag switch. Depending on the format string and time passed since previous -ag use, generated and existing archive names may mismatch. In this case WinRAR will create a new archive instead of updating the already existing. Examples: 1) use the default YYYYMMDDHHMMSS format winrar a -ag backup 2) use DD-MMM-YY format winrar a -agDD-MMM-YY backup 3) use YYYYMMDDHHMM format, place date before 'backup' winrar a -ag+YYYYMMDDHHMM backup 4) use YYYY-WW-A format, include fields description winrar a -agYYYY{year}-WW{week}-A{wday} backup 5) use YYYYMMDD and the archive number. It allows to generate unique names even when YYYYMMDD format mask used more than once in the same day winrar a -agYYYYMMDD-NN backup

item.title: #1100 Repack ZIP files during archiving
item.detail: Many file types, not only ZIP itself but also MS Office 2007/2010 (xslx,docx etc), Java JAR, Mozilla XPI and many other, are de facto ZIP archives. When 7-Zip packs a set containing such files, it cannot gain considerable compressing ratio because of ZIP archives are pseudorandom binary files. If 7-Zip will repack content of such files on-the-fly using LZMA algorithm, it may gain significally better compression ratio. Of course, when 7-Zip will unpack an archive containing repacked ZIP file, it shall repack a LZMA-packed content in a ZIP file on-the-fly. This proposition may also be helpful for CAB, MSI and other common packed file formats.

item.title: #703 Change Compression Level & Method in 7 Zip File Manager

We don't want the split the archives since they are just a little over the size of a blank DVD. We would like a feature to select a file or folder in the archive using the 7-zip file manager, right mouse click, and change the compression level and/or method. This would allow a user to change the size of an archive without deleting a folder or two and then adding them back to the desired archive. This should also preserve file and folder timestamps. Extracting and re-archiving will maintain file timestamps but folder timestamps are lost. Wishful for your consideration of our request in future releases. Anyhow, Great Product!

item.title: #349 Store, don't try to compress certain files

A default list might include: 7z zip cab bz2 jpg mp3 ... ----- In fact, here is Winrar's note on the subject: -ms[list] Specify file types to store. Specify file types, which will be stored without compression. This switch may be used to store already compressed files, which helps to increase archiving speed without noticeable loss in the compression ratio. Optional parameter defines the list of file extensions separated by semicolons. For example, -msrar;zip;jpg will force RAR to store without compression all RAR and ZIP archives and JPG images. It is also allowed to specify wildcard file masks in the list, so -ms*.rar;*.zip;*.jpg will work too. If is not specified, -ms switch will use the default set of extensions, which includes the following file types: ace, arj, bz2, cab, gz, jpeg, jpg, lha, lzh, mp3, rar, zip, taz, tgz, z ----- talves@gmail.com

item.title: #981 Avoid file/disk fragmentation during decompression
item.detail: ISSUE: Especially large files decompressed by 7-ZIP are created from the start with significant file fragmentation on the disk. CAUSE: 7-ZIP seems to write-out decompressed file content to disk incrementally just as their content becomes available by the "unzip"-engine. Therefore a 100MB file will initially start with a length of zero bytes and then grow incrementally in small steps. As the operation system initially never knows how large the file will become in the end the OS has to incrementally reserve new disk space for each and every of these "growth"-steps. -> In most cases this will not be possible in a continuous manner on the hard disk - therefore creating many file fragments all over the disk even at the time of file creation. FIX/IMPROVEMENT: => Tell the OS how large the file will become in the end! -> As this is during decompression 7-ZIP knows exactly how large each uncompressed file will be HOWTO: Just set the expected file size directly after initially creating the file. On Windows using the Win32 API this would look something like this (without any error checking): HANDLE hFile; LARGE_INTEGER liSize; hFile = CreateFile("somelargefile.bin", GENERIC_WRITE, FILE_SHARE_READ, 0, CREATE_NEW, FILE_FLAG_SEQUENTIAL_SCAN, 0); liSize.LowPart = 1234567890; liSize.HighPart = 0; SetFilePointerEx(hFile, liSize , NULL, FILE_BEGIN); SetEndOfFile(hFile); SetFilePointer(hFile, 0, NULL, FILE_BEGIN); The SetEndOfFile call is were it all happens in the OS. On NTFS this call performs very fast and still pre-allocates the full physical disk space for the file (look up doc for SetEndOfFile and how it works together with SetFileValidData to avoid the need to zero-fill the complete file which would slow down things). CAVEAT: This method only works (i.e. prevent fragmentation) if the file is not configured as a SPARSE-file (supported by NTFS, ext3/4, and many others). On Windows CreateFile never creates a SPARSE-file, this would need an additional call to DeviceIoControl. However, I've no idea if this is also true for other OS/other FS - I think so, but I'm not 100% sure. On other OS the same principle applies just as long as the OS and the file-system drivers support using this "size-hint" to create less fragmented files. For example, AFAIK, Linux works partially like this as well (e.g. see "shake" defragmenter for Linux)... Thanks for creating the best archiving tool out there! This highly technical point really is my onlyissue with 7-ZIP... Cheers, Marble.

This would speed up compression process significantly and there would be almost no difference in compressed size comparing to the result where no such a method was used. I have written .NET wrapper where I can set the properties (including compression ratio) for the whole archive using IOutArchive.SetProperties COM method. But there is no option to set compression ratio separately per each item. In SharpZipLib library I can specify the compression level per each item writing something like this: ZipEntry entry = new ZipEntry(name); string extension = Path.GetExtension(source).ToLower(); entry.CompressionMethod = compressedExtensions.Contains(extension) ? CompressionMethod.Stored : CompressionMethod.Deflated; I didn't find the way how to achieve this in 7-zip. Is there a solution? In my opinion this is key feature.

item.title: #538 Please make LZMA command line more like gzip and bzip2
item.detail: Hi Igor, I am the Debian maintainer in charge of the LZMA package (a binary build from the LZMA_Alone directory of the SDK). In order to get lzma used in the Debian Packages structure, we need DPKG to support lzma as it supports gzip and bzip2. DPKG's maintainers and many other people would like lzma to have an interface similar to those tools (they reported bug reports to me, so I am just forwarding them). That is to say: % lzma --version LZMA 4.43 Copyright (c) 1999-2006 Igor Pavlov 2006-06-04 % lzma -vvv -> verbose versions but silent by default % lzma file -> compressed file.lzma as output [ equivalent to the current % lzma e file file.lz ] % unlzma file.lz -> uncompressed file as output [ equivalent to the current % lzma d file.lz file ] % echo foo | lzma -> write encoded data to the terminal [ equivalent to the current % echo foo | lzma e -si -so ] % echo foo | lzma | unlzma -> write foo to the terminal [ equivalent to the current % echo foo | lzma e -si -so | lzma d -si -so ] I think this should be really easy to implement for you and it has the advantage to make lzma a real competitor to gzip and bzip2 on Unix platforms. I am also working on having a tar flag for LZMA. And I think the maintainers will have the same concerns about the command-line interface of LZMA. Moreover, there is already some work done (see ). It would be great to merge some of the functionnalities already there. What do you think? When would you be able to do it? As Debian is releasing soon, DPKG is going to be frozen really soon now. And if we do not provide the lzma feature now, we will have to wait a release cycle to get it integrated and then another one to see the feature really used (because of transition issues...). Anyways, thanks for considering.

item.title: #556 generate archive name using the current date and time
item.detail: Please add support to automatically generate archive names equivalent to the winrar -AG[format] switch. This would permit automatic backup scripts to easily create unique named archives, complete with embedded date info. I am stuck with winrar until 7zip adds support for this. I did see #1395142, but it didn't seem to be very clear. example: -ag" YYYY-MMM-DD HHMM" This appends the date string specified to the archive name already provided, note the space I have included. Winrar will prefix the date string instead if it starts with a '+'. I think the '+' format specifier is a little counterintuitive, and I would prefer to depreciate it in favour of a replacement format specifier of L to cause any leafname specified to be embedded into the generated name, wherever placed in the format string. In the absence of an L specifier, then compatibility with the winrar syntax should (if possible) be maintained. Inclusion of both an initial + and an L should probably generate an error, but inclusion of multiple instances of L should perhaps be permitted. This switch also supports the N format specifier, which causes the archiver to search for any preexisting archive name, and create new names with incremental numbers if necessary. [personally, i find having hour(H), minute(M), and on rare occasions second(S) is sufficient for creating unique names, but i suppose someone may just want predictable incremental numbered names in some situations, and no date info] See winrar helpfile for complete details :)

item.title: #965 Better handling of multi-part archive extraction
item.detail: 7-zip does not uncompress multi-part RAR archives properly. Say I have a multi-part archive that starts with .RAR, .R00,.R01, ... .R99. In WinRAR you can click on any of the other files other then the one that has the .RAR extension and the archive will unzip properly. However if you do that in 7-Zip if fails miserably, it seems to want to start uncompressing from that archive you've selected and fails instead of being smart enough to go to the beginning of the archive. I'd expect that if I click on MyArchive.R05 right click and go to extract all, that it would be smart enough to know that is not the beginning of the archive and find it's way to MyArchive.RAR and begin the extraction. Think of the scenario where you have 5 multi-part archives each 200 pieces all in one directory. What this forces me to do is go search out all the files that begin with .RAR and extract them instead of clicking on any of the archive pieces from each of the five multi-part archives and extracting them. Sure you could sort by .RAR then extract and then go back to your last view of the directory but that is unnecessary clicking. So I propose that you support the option of clicking on MyArchive.R05 or any of the .RXX files that are associated with 7Zip and have it proceed to find the beginning of the archive and then extract the files, just like the way WinRAR does it. This would provide much needed flexibility in the programs usage. FYI, i'm refering the 7zip for windows. See forum post here for more information:

item.title: #385 7z command-line : no option to overwrite archive
item.detail: Unless I'm wrong in my findings, there is no way for the command-line 7z to "overwrite" an existing archiving. Something like a 'c' action (Create) which would be similar to 'a' (Add) but would overwrite the previous archive. Today the only way to create a new archive 'test.7z' is to make sure that file does not exist yet, then to issue something like : 7z a test.7z myfiles If test.7z does not exist, it will be created. If test.7z already exists, there is NO way to tell 7z to overwrite it. This can usefull when using temporary files in more complex scripts. For instance I need to get a temp file name from Windows. Then I need to create an archive of that name. This is not easy. Because when windows gives you a temp file name, it creates the file with 0 bytes content. Hence the file already exists for 7z and 7z fails with an error about the file being not a supported archive format (correct, it is right). So the only solution is to delete the temp file returned by windows just before running 7z. But this opens the risk that windows could assign that same file name to another temp file name request while or before 7z runs. A switch for the action 'a' that would allow to overwrite the existing archive or maybe better a completetly distinct action 'c' (Create) would be really usefull. It would have exactly the same options and semantic as action 'a' (Add), except that it would always create a new archive, overwriting the archive name if it already exists.

item.title: #182 Please UPX *.SFX in your project
item.detail: Hi have you ever heard of UPX? It's a lossleless compressor for .exe files. They are compressed and decompressed in memory just before executing. You can read about it in greater detail and get a copy at HTTP://UPX.SF.NET. UPX is simply a must have. Here's an example of what it can do to .EXEs: ----------------------------------------------------------- Application Original Compressed Ratio ----------------------------------------------------------- Netscape 4.06 netscape.exe 2,934,336 1,124,352 Descent 2 descent2.exe 1,448,873 652,832 MAME 0.36 mame.exe 8,214,016 1,810,056 OneOhOne 101.exe 438,144 179,566 Emacs 20.2 emacs-20.2 2,772,657 925,543 g++ 2.8.1 cc1plus.ttp 1,595,049 655,508 ----------------------------------------------------------- Total 17,403,075 5,347,857 Please UPX *.SFX (your self-extracting .exes) so that they'll be as small as possible. I've already tested out this lossless compression on your program and it works great. You can download a copy at Thanks, Christian Blackburn

item.title: #813 Compression Improvement - identify files inside CD images
item.detail: Firstly lets start with an example. Try compressing a .iso image normally (with no subchannel or copyprotection data) Now compress the contents of the .iso as indiviual files. You will note that compressing the files individually provides a much better compression ratio. It would be fantastic if 7Zip could understand popular image formats nativly and compress the image by trying to identify the files rather than compressing one big data stream. May I suggest a way to do this: When a supported CD image format is detected of being compressed, 7zip identifies the indiviual files and their location inside the CD image, compresses them just as if they were loose files on your hard drive, identify the subchannel data along with all the other bits that are not files, (their location in the image too) and compress that like a special file. When decompressing, 7zip uses the available info to recreate the cd/dvd image in its exact original form.

item.title: #711 Password management within file manager
item.detail: It'd be really nice if you could add/edit/delete passwords within existing archives via the file manager. Right now the only real option for adding passwords to archives is to put add your archive to a NEW archive at "store" level compression and add a password to the outside one. The only way to delete the password from your archive (other than the way described in the bug fixes forum) is to extract all and rearchive. The same goes for changing the password. I think it could work the same way I suggested in the post for that password deletion bug. If you want to delete the password, it would prompt you for your old password and then simply unencrypt the current archive (or as I seem to recall, it recreates the archive within a temp file in the same directory and then overwrites the original). If you wanted to change the password it would just prompt for the new password after it prompted for the old one and then it would simply apply the new password. I realize this probably would not be able to be implemented on .rar archives because it would most likely involve rebuilding the archive, which is a no-no with winrar's proprietary algorithm, but still, it would be nice, at least with the native .7z format.

item.title: #962 Idea for lowering file size of solid multi-block 7Z files
item.detail: Currently, the method to assign files to blocks in 7Z files goes something like this: 1. Group files by extension 2. Sort groups alphabetically 3. Sort files within groups alphabetically 4. Start at top of list, try to add file to the block. Repeat. 5. When block doesn't have room, start a new block. This often results in blocks that are much smaller than the user-specified block size, and often uses more blocks than are necessary, which typically makes the final 7Z file size larger than they need to be. I would recommend: 1. Group files by extension 2. Sort groups by file size (decreasing) 3. Sort files within groups by file size (decreasing) 4. Start at top of list, try to add an entire group to the block. Repeat. 5. When block doesn't have room for any more complete groups, start at top of list (disregarding groupings) and add a single file to the block. Repeat. 6. When block doesn't have room for any more files at all, re-sort remaining groups by file size and start a new block. This should result in blocks being packed as tightly as possible, while still favoring the current logic of trying to keep files with the same extension in the same block. This will increase 7-Zip usefulness in low-RAM environments where block sizes are the limiting factor.

item.title: #794 compression improvement: better duplicate file handling
item.detail: Compression improvement: better duplicate file handling This is a feature request that can significantly improve the compression ratio of archives that have duplicate files in them, particularly if the duplicated files are larger than the dictionary size. The name and location of these files does not matter (i.e. they may be in the same folder under different names, under different folders, etc.). Use cases: 1.) improving compression ratios of solid and non-solid archives 2.) backups of filesystems with hardlinks in them 3.) drive backups of the whole filesystem, including programs: there are many gigabytes of duplicated DLLs in a complete file-based backup of a Windows drive. Many of these duplicates come from programs keeping a copy of DLLs in their own folder. 4.) Driverpacks ( ) also have many duplicated DLLs in them due to how they must be organized into multiple folders to separate drivers One possible algorithm: 1.) During the standard 7-Zip compression process a CRC is generated for each file. Record this CRC and the file size together in a table. 2.) as part of adding each new file to the archive, compare the CRC and file size of the new file to the table of all other files already in the archive. 3.) If there isn't a CRC and file size match, continue processing the file as 7-Zip normally would. (Traditional processing technique) 4.) If there IS a CRC and file size match, begin a byte-for-byte comparison of the two files to verify 100% that they are identical. (This byte-for-byte comparison *might* be replaced with a very strong hashing function, but that's still not as safe as a true byte-for-byte comparison. The default CRC32 is strong enough to quickly weed out non-identical files, but not strong enough to ensure they are truly identical. After all, users expect lossless compression to be guaranteed with 7-Zip.) 5.) If the byte-for-byte comparison succeeds (the files are truly identical), add an entry in the 7-Zip file table that upon decompression directs 7-Zip to use the same compressed source bytes of data as for the identical file. On Unix-like systems this would be like a creating a hardlink to a file (a pointer to the same data + a reference counter). 6.) If the byte-for-byte comparison failed, continue processing the file as 7-Zip normally would. (and possibly note somewhere in the archive that even though the CRC matches, the files were not identical). ---- Note: an enhancement of this algorithm would be to check the filesystem for hardlink between the two files in question, and use that as an alternative to the byte-for-byte comparison. (If they're hardlinked to the same place, there is no reason to do the byte-for-byte comparison.) Fully implemented, this might use recreate hardlinks upon restoration. (NTFS does support hardlinks, just not via the GUI).

item.title: #1110 Include archive offset in Info dialog for SFX archives

This is a pretty central piece of information for a self-extracting archive and worthy of being shown in the archive info either directly ("archive offset") or indirectly ("SFX module size"). FreeArc is an example of an archiver that reveals this information, taking the latter approach.

item.title: #1005 RFE: store *nix file owner and groups
item.detail: Store GID (GroupID) and UID (UserID) of linux/unix files. The G/UID are two 32 bit integers associated with file owner and file group, unique on an installation (like are unique group/username). G/UID=0 is used by root. The max supported value is 2^31-1. Association between G/UID and group/usernames, is done by those files: /etc/passwd (for user) /etc/group (for group) and the corresponding system call. For example to see files G/UID, a simple command parameter is needed: $ ls -ln while: $ ls -l show the complete groups and usernames. Note: Every files can be part of many groups, but 99% of applications need the main group only, so also a partial support is appreciated.

item.title: #771 Recompress existing archives
item.detail: I would like to see an optional feature whereby if you are creating an archive, and some of the files being added are themselves archives that 7-zip supports, instead of trying to compress the archive, it on-the-fly writes a header indicating the original archive type and compression format, then decompresses the embedded archive to memory and recompresses the data using whatever options are in effect for the outer archive being created. Then when such an archive is decompressed, the header is parsed, and the content from the nested archive is recompressed into its original format before being written to disk. This would mean if you were creating a .7z archive that contained .zip files, you would get a much smaller .7z archive as it can compress the raw data extracted from the zips better than the zip files themselves. The cost, of course, would be slower extract times, and it would probably be impractical to make it compatible with SFX archives.

item.title: #1121 Command line - Feature Request
item.detail: Dear developers. As a long time rar user, one of these days I decided to search for a free open-source alternative to it the way I could replace my backup script (Windows batch), so I chose 7z beacause of it's features. It's open-source, very good compression ratio compared to rar and supports AES encryption. First of all I'm going to describe what I use with rar so you can better understand: Fast compression ratio Include and exclude files from list using Create a archive name in the form archive_date(yyyymmdd)-time(hhmmss).rar Here is the command I use: rar a -r -k -m1 -p"password" -ep3 -x@exclude_list.txt -ag_yyyymmdd-hhmmss archive.rar @include_list.txt As I was testing I found the problems discribed bellow that frustated my switch to 7z and kept me with rar. Problem 1: As the files lists from .txt files include files from multiple locations (including multiple drives), I need to use the switch -ep3 in rar to store the full paths including the drive letter. This is crutial because I need to know from here the files come from when I made the backup. I couldn't achieve the same with 7z because I was unable to find any similar option in the 7z switches list. I tested 7z with option but no full paths were stored, so I ended up with a bunch of files and directories that didn't make much sense. With rar we have the following switches: ep Exclude paths from names ep1 Exclude base directory from names ep2 Expand paths to full ep3 Expand paths to full including the drive letter Problem 2: As you may had notice in my rar command, I append the current date and time to the name of the archive for obvious reasons. I also could not achieve this with 7z because I didn't found any switch that could allow me to do the same. But this time yes, I was able to append the date and time as I did with rar using the command date from CoreUtils (Windows version of date command sucks). But I think this feature should be implemented. The rar switch that allows append current date and time no the archive name: ag[format] Generate archive name using the current date I think that for using 7z to make backup routines these features are extremelly importante and should be implemented. Thank you, Pedro Cunha

item.title: #814 Support for Mac archives
item.detail: Formats: Stuffit (.sit and .sitx), MacBinary(.bin) (uncompressed), and BinHex(.hqx) in particular. .bin is trivial, and .hqx shouldn't be too hard. Note that on Macintosh systems, a file may have more than one "fork" of data, unlike most other operating systems, and this is reflected in the archive formats. Often, only the data fork is wanted/need be extracted. But sometimes the resource fork, or both, are needed. In that case, there a couple of conventions, so offer a choice: 1. Append ".data" to the name of the extracted data fork and ".rsrc" to the name of the extracted resource fork. (Also, I've seen connected ".info" files, but I don't know about them). 2. Decompress to MacBinary, since it is so simple (128-byte header, followed by each fork padded to a multiple of 128 bytes). Information on various formats: in that folder, /macunpack/ , an unpacking program, is explicitly non-copyrighted according to the readme Anything uploaded on that site must be freely redistributable by (although not necessarily compatible with the LGPL) by: Reverse-engineered stuffit specs: BinHex (.hqx) MacBinary (dead, but available on Wayback. Or available in code from that Czech site) _iii.html

item.title: #1084 7z command line logging
item.detail: When syntax is correct 7z works fairly flawlessly creating and unpacking archives. However, whenever a syntax error or archive creation/extraction error occurs it becomes essential for automation to parse the log file to verify an error has occurred. Working with the windows command prompt output redirect is not always the cleanest solution. Often I find working with script languages that call shellexecute( ) easier and cleaner with less probability of generating syntax errors due to sloppy placement of a rogue apostrophe or quotation marks. I believe that adding a command line logging switch to 7zip would be a project essential. The "-l" is taken already for listing files in an archive. I propose 7zip use either "-lo" for log output or "-log". The user specified value would be the full file path and file name for the log generated. The default behavior should be to append to file if it exists rather than overwrite or provide any options since the user can easily control this by other means via unique file naming or deleting the existing file if they so please.

item.title: #1058 Automatic crash reporting
item.detail: To make 7-Zip more stable it is very helpful to automatically generate and send crash reports. Generating crash report manually and manually submitting it into bug tracker is very complicated procedure for most of the users. And even these how can make it prefer to not waste their time. Automatic submission (by one click or no clicks at all) raises crash reports flow in thousands times. That big flow can drive developer's efforts to a right direction when these bugs fixed first that affects most users and not one that has a time to submit it in a bug tracker. There is a statistics that 1 percent of top crash bugs fixes 50% of all crashes: In recent months, Microsoft has learned that 80 percent of the errors and crashes in Windows and Office are caused by 20 percent of the entire pool of bugs detected, and that more than 50 percent of the headaches derive from a mere 1 percent of all flawed code. I represent a crash reporting and analyzing service. I would like to suggest adding to 7-Zip of crash report sending feature for free. In very short it looks like this: 7-Zip crashes, the user is offered to send the crash report to the manufacturer. The report is uploaded, system analyzes it and then group it with similar problems. Further developers can download the interesting memory dump, open it in a debugger and try to find and fix a bug. Key feature is that all of that does automatically in ¡°one click¡±. Experience shows that almost no users send a crash report if this require any difficult actions (sending an e-mail or registering in bug tracker is difficult enough). One click is so easy way that some users do it (many users do not do even this). Other key feature is that all preprocessing of crash reports is done for you. You have no need to open each report and see that you already has fixed it. The small description and demonstration are accessible here: Also you can open a demo project and browse a little: (Login as Guest) I will be happy to answer any your questions, comments and opinions at info@crash-server.com

item.title: #1108 Discourage using dictionary larger than uncompressed data

When this ceiling is encountered, leave the previously used value in place as the default for the next time. This request applies to LZMA(2) and any other algorithms for which a dictionary larger than the data is simply stupid. (Even if/though 7-zip were/is smart when decompressing and did/does not allocate a larger dictionary than the uncompressed data size, other tools might be simpler and should be given a hand when it's so easy to do so.) (As a matter of principle, I don't think the user should be left *unable* to use a larger dictionary than the uncompressed data, but they should certainly have to go out of their way to do so.)

item.title: #125 Estimated File Size...
item.detail: I would suggest adding this feature to the "Compressing XYZ%" dialog box. Esentially, it would estimate the file size by dividing the current size of the output file by the percentage completed. In the first 10% or so the ammount will likely be much higher (a 120Mb file could project a 900Mb final archive) than the actual archive will be so I recommend putting a cap on the display of 10% of the total file size. You also may want to /not/ display the estimate until after the first 10% have completed for this reason. Math Example: Variables: Percentage Complete (Compressing XYZ%) -------- Current File Size (Temp File) -------- Actual File Size (Size of Original) Current File Size / X.YZ = Estimated File Size where Estimated File Size <= Actual File Size * 1.10 display Estimated File Size else display Actual File Size * 1.10 Compressing Dialog Examples: EG 1 Compressing 1% Elapsed Time: --- 00:10 ------ Actual Size: --- 151Mb Remaining Time: - 10:50 ----- Estimated Size: - 166Mb /EG 1 EG 2 Compressing 50% Elapsed Time: --- 06:10 ------ Actual Size: --- 151Mb Remaining Time: - 05:50 ----- Estimated Size: - 145Mb /EG 2

item.title: #258 Smart single-folder archive extraction
item.detail: A lot of archives contain a single folder with all its contents within. For instance, OpenOffice.org for Windows has binary archives named OOo_x.x.x_Win32Intel_install.zip that each contain a single folder named OOo_x.x.x_Win32Intel_install, which matches the archive filename. 7-Zip has a command to extract the archive to a folder of the same name, but if it extracts the above example file with this method, the user will end up with the unnecessarily two-level folder structure OOo_x.x.x_Win32Intel_install\OOo_x.x.x_Win32Intel_install\, the bottom-most level of course containing the files. Instead, in situations like the above, when the "Extract to OOo_x.x.x_Win32Intel_install\" command is selected, 7-Zip should just extract the contents of the single compressed folder to OOo_x.x.x_Win32Intel_install\, which would end up being the same as selecting "Extract here," except the user doesn't have to open the archive and have the optional intuition to decide which command is best.

item.title: #1033 Emulate solid archiving for ZIP files
item.detail: Even though ZIP files does not support solid archiving, this can be emulated as in .tar.gz archives, i.e. 1. add all the files to a ZIP archive with no compression (STORE) 2. add the above resulting archive to a ZIP archive with compression (optionally add some kind of solid-flag to tell the decompressor that this is a solid archive) Note that this approach is mostly backward compatible because existing decompressors will be able to extract the files just fine (obviously they will need to extract the uncompressed archive first, and then extracting the files from it). OTOH if the zip decompressor is solid-flag-aware it could choose to do the double decompression on the fly.

item.title: #1025 "Lax" archive parsing
item.detail: I have encountered numerous files over time, mostly ZIPs, that cannot be extracted by 7-Zip, giving either an error or a corrupted file. Those same ZIP files work fine in say, WinRAR, or WinZIP. I know this is because 7-Zip doesn't tolerate corrupt file data, however sometimes there is no way to get a new ZIP (the corrupted one is all that is available). Rather than having to keep a copy of WinRAR for those occasions, how feasible would it be to implement a "lax" archive parser, that could be enabled via a checkbox, or as a fallback option should the primary parser fail. There are many small errors in a ZIP file that should not be fatal (such as disk numbering not starting at zero). This would eliminate many users' need for a second ZIP solution, and allow them to move entirely to 7-Zip.

item.title: #910 7ZFM: multiple compression profiles for each archive format
item.detail: Although 7-Zip File Manager already stores compression settings for each archive type, it only stores 1 setting, which is inadequate for archives formats that support multiple compression methods, and it isn't just .7z archive. For example, the BZip2 and PPMd compress text files better than binary files, while LZMA and LZMA2 compress binary files better than text files. Compression sizes aside, methods such as PPMd use large amount of memory during decompression, which can cause archives to become unusable in embedded environments unless the parameters are re-tuned. The ability to store multiple command line settings per archive type will save user the hassle of retyping the command lines over and over, and improve usability for installer package building.

item.title: #637 Sort order of files for creation should be optional
item.detail: I understand 7-ZIP sorts files, primarily by extension, and then by basename (or something like that) to aid 'solid' compression I suppose. This sorting should be able to be disabled for reasons set out below of corrupt/partial archives, and because sometimes the user knows better than 7-zip!!! I would like to see the option of DISABLING the sort order, instead using the canonical file-system order. Reason: We make big archives (hundreds of Megabytes) from thousands of folder. The sort order makes a real mess of things if we get a corruption in an archive or a partial archive - This can happen fairly regularly when we are shipping such big archives. Often, to us, a partial archive is OK for our purposes. But the 7-ZIP sort order means that if we lose a bit of the archive it 'damages' many of our thousands of sub-folders. It 'spreads out' the damage over many sub-folders. It would be better the damage be localised to the minimum number of folders for the 'lost part' of the archive. (When we get partial sub-folders they essentially become unusable to us.) Further, the files in these sub-folders ARE likely to be similar to each other. - NOT compressing them together could result in WORSE compression. 7-ZIP should not assume it is smarter than it's users... Anyway, I strongly support that there SHOULD be an option to turn off the sorting of files as they go into the archive...

Very efficient, provided that the program issues many file requests in a queue without waiting each one to be completed. Could 7z implement it ? This needs to use ReadFile() with FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED. I believe it works on Win Nt4, 2k, Xp, 2k3 and their successors, but not on W95-98-98se-Me. The attached file contains an explanation. Thanks! item.title: #1042 enforce WinZip compatibility with .ZIP selection

Or, (2) add a click box that would force this. Or (3) minimally, just put add an indicator - like ZD (for ZIP-DEFAULT) to the appropriate line in the section list so its easy to know and pick the most compatible settings Why its important: The only reason to write a .ZIP instead of a .7z file, is to make it compatible with WinZip, Stuffit, and all other ZIP applications. It is a huge frustration that makes people junk 7-zip when it writes a .zip file that other people cant read. THANKS!!

item.title: #404 Incremental backup functionality
item.detail: I propose an added feature that might require an extension to the 7z file format: Say I've got 2-3 GB worth of compressed files to back up, and I'd like to record these files' contents for each day, without reproducing the whole archive each time. Ok, so first, create the initial archive, on 2005-10-06. The next day, 2005-10-07, use a -u switch like the one in your help file: >7z u c:\1\exist.7z -u- -up0q3x2z0!c:\1\update.7z * -r But imagine, if you will, a different update switch where the new file information would be appended to the original archive, so you have one file that contains both the original backup and the updated information. Then, on top of that you could run an additional backup on 2005-10-08, and further append the difference to the original archive. Ultimately, you have a file that contains multiple versions of files that are updated frequently, but only one copy of those files that have remained the same.

item.title: #219 Special algo for ISO images
item.detail: Many compressed files are .iso files (of bin) --------------------------------------- I'm not an expert in the ISO format, but I think that you have some recovery data that is well defined. I don't know how the algo is defined. Sample: this is an array of binary datas a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 c1 c2 c3 c4 c5 d1 d2 d3 d4 d5 e1 e2 e3 e4 e5 ISO will store the data like a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 (a1+a2+a3+a4+a5) b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 (b1+b2+b3+b4+b5) c1 c2 c3 c4 c5 (c1+c2+c3+c4+c5) d1 d2 d3 d4 d5 (d1+d2+d3+d4+d5) e1 e2 e3 e4 e5 (e1+e2+e3+e4+e5) s1 s2 s3 s4 s5 s6 Where s[x] = a[x]+b[x]+c[x]+d[x]+e[x] So instead of storing 25 bytes... we store 36 bytes. But we are able to recover 1 error. (I think the CDRom algo is more evolued) It would be cool if in the algorythm used to compress+decompress we remove and regenerate this missing information. --------------------------------------------------- another important point. Imagine you want to store: "hello, hello and hello, hellohellohello" A way to store it is to say (The algo in 7Zip is more efficent I hope :-) ) "5hello@1, @1 and @1, @1@1@1" When you store using some recovery method "hel[h+e+l]lo, [o+,+ ]hel[h+e+l]lo [... Here we cannot find the word "hello"... --------------------------------------------------- So the algo compress become if (look like an iso) { remove_iso_checksum; } compress_like_before() So the algo decompress decompress_like_before() if (look like an iso) { add_iso_checksum; } Gab

item.title: #1095 7-zip should use parallel decompress to avoid bad behavior
item.detail: 7-zip runs abysmally slow on modern machines doing decompression, when it could easily run 4-6 x faster on most machines and 8-12 times faster on many. As it isn't even close to being I/O bound (writing decompressed files at 13MB/s on disks capable of over 50 times that speed), this would be like detroit building a car for a moddern highway that can only do 3 MPH... Most people would consider than unacceptable performance -- even a bug, but some will response that is performance according to it's designed specification -- and by that definition, it isn't a bug. But from a performance standpoint -- I don't think it would pass modern QA standards I was getting 10MB / s 10 years ago with gzip!... and that was on compression....here we are talking uncompression which is supposed to be faster... I guess I don't get why decompression is so slow...? Anyway, as 'implied', it seemed you wanted this added as a feature request as running with a 86-93% performance penalty isn't considered a bug. Ok. I don't care... just as long as it gets addressed at some point -- but obviously, if it was important enough for me -- I'd do it myself and send you the patch or release it or something...;-) I have a reasonably fast machine. 3.33GHz (6 core Xeon), yet on decompressing a file 7-zip achieves an astounding rate of 15MB/s... fully broken. The disk is a RAID0 of SSD's easily capable of well over 100MB/s (200-400 is more typical). Even a single HD can usually write over 100MB/s. So using parallel decompression on a 6-core processor would, for most people not saturate their HD. With increasingly common RAID and SSD setups, it wouldn't even touch 1/3-1/4 the bandwidth (if I did it on my server -- - it's got a 1GB/s write rate... so 15MB/s when unpacking a 4GB archive is unreasonably slow given current I/O speeds and parallel options... This would ***presume*** the archive was not packed as 1 continuous block, but used, say, block sizes of that made parallelism, possible -- something I've learned to do since I found (surprisingly) that a larger block size isn't always smaller. By default I used a 1G BS (64MBdic, 128bit word)... I found this was quite a bit less than optimal.. (I'm running a program that often needs to access / extract parts of a .7z archive to repair damage created when one switches around load load orders (game=oblivion). I figured a smaller block size would make so it didn't have to unpack as many blocks to access the files it needed (vs. if it is a 1GB or solid blocksize, it would need to compress linearly from the beginning as I understand it. So I ran several tests and better than my previous defaults were several smaller block sizes with the best being 'a solid archive at max word size and 1GB dictionary.' Chart: src=346,735,328 (338601K, 338668K alloc) test compressions BS(MB) dic(MB) Word size(K) (Overhead) 1024 64 128 270796 1.77% larger 64 32 64 269708 1.36% larger 64 32 32 269696 1.36% larger 64 32 24 269696 1.36% larger 64 32 16 269692 1.36% larger 64 48 32 269528 1.30% larger 64 48 24 269528 1.30% larger 64 48 16 269520 1.29% larger 64 64 32 269468 1.27% larger 64 64 24 269468 1.27% larger 64 64 16 268462 0.89% larger 64 64 16 268462 0.89% larger solid 1024 273 266082 0.00% larger ---- Of course this would vary depending on the data compressed, but a 64MB MB block size with 64MB dict and 16bit word gave results darn close to optimal. So... For these files I'm using a 64MB block size. My test file above was 5. x 64MB, meaning it likely could have been decompressed in parallel given enough memory to buffer things. That's something that would have to be taken into account when activating multiple decompression threads unless the final uncompressed size of each block is known in advance. Regardless the entire file's post-allocated size *should* be pre-allocated (NOTE -- this should be done in even a non-parallel compress so the OS allocates 1 large chunk to hold the whole file). Another risk if you write small chunks -- some other process might ask for allocations in the middle of your file. In any event, you can see that in even my small test file -- 6 threads would help, and on my server, with the 1GB/s RAID and 12 threads, parallelism would kick butt! ;-) Thanks, Astara

item.detail: When opening a tar.gz (or tar.bz2) archive in the 7-zip GUI, only a single tar file is shown. If you want to see the content of that file, you need to decompress it to a temporary file and open it. It would be very usefull if 7-zip could show the contents of the tar file directly!

item.title: #643 Missing Partial Files
item.detail: When extracting from a split archive with one or more parts missing, it would be nice if 7-Zip would tell you the file it was expecting (as is the case in WinRAR), rather than giving the more general CRC failure message.

item.title: #283 combining of splited files
item.detail: Exampe: Splitting Setup.exe in two parts, then Extract here. And it extracts not one Setup.exe file, but the content of Setup.exe. I know that i have to turn on FM and go to Combine menu. But its more convinient to Combine files through Context Menu. Maybe some Combine Here entry for splitted files in Context menu?

item.title: #985 fresh look for the new windows versions
item.detail: I use two systems, Ubuntu and Win7. Under ubuntu i've never seen 7zip gui, but under windows i use gui usually. Maybe under Windows XP it looks normal and native, but under Vista and Windows 7 it looks very ugly and old. we need: aero glass support 32-bit icons win7 taskbar support (progressbar, jump-menu) I don't know c++, but if i can help, i could.

item.title: #443 Custom file size split option
item.detail: Hi, The archive utility should have custom file size splitting options. Currently there is option for splitting the same to a floppy, CD and DVD, the same has to be extended to the custom sizes.

item.title: #246 7-zip benchmarks as seprate tool
item.detail: i really like the 7-zip benchmark feaures and use it for benchmarking memory tweaking. and also stability testing 2 questions i got. 1: would you consider releasing a stand-alone version of the 7-zip benchmark 2: how god is is to find emmory/cpu errors compared to actually archiving files end decompres them workihn with files give me these steps CRCR32 calculations compresion decompresion CRC32 calculate CRC compare if there is an erros in just one of these step the crc32 compareing would show it how is it compared to the benchmarks. Are you doing crc32 compares on the data that are compressed ?

item.title: #447 dispplay archive name in the window/icon title
item.detail: I found that 7zip does not display the archive name in its window title at all. When more than one archive is open this causes some confusion. It could even use the explorer preferences to (not) show the full pathname in the window title.

item.title: #355 Cascaded Context Menu
item.detail: Default the "Cascaded Context Menu" setting to enabled. I am sure more people apprecite it that way, it puts all items into one submenu which makes it easier since its categorized in one place, it makes less clutter, etc. Adding a icon would be a good idea too.

item.title: #802 improved effectiveness
item.detail: Dear Igor Pavlov, dear developers, Beside that your packer is a real great piece of software(!!!), I want to point to an amazing difference in efficency under some circumstances between the "standard" 7Z.exes, compared to the 7-Zip TotalCommander plugin "7zip.wcx" (tested with several versions .0.5x). MY RESULTS WERE 1 differences are NOT really depending on setting of number of "fast bytes" 2 but very much depending on number of identical data in the package! 3 Prepacked data is better compressed by the Plugin, too. (allways assuming having and using enough RAM...) EXAMPLE FILE SET A very good (but no exclusive) example is "ar9lite_deu.exe" (Acrobat Reader lite, GERMAN package): Download: _deu.exe THE RESULT IS ALMOST 10% BETTER WITH THE .WCX-PLUGIN than with 7z 4.xx! You can easily reproduce this by yourself. If the reason for this can easily be found out and if its not too hard to implement new switches/functions, I would suggest switches like: -ap : assume (much) prepacked Data -ar : assume (much) redundant Data PS: Another, even older idea of mine is to implement a mode which produces a variety of possible approaches to get best packing results; the name of the output file could, for example, reflect the used switches, added as part of the name of the output file. With kind regards Wolfgang Satorius w.satorius@nixneues.de

item.title: #459 Missing Field
item.detail: I thought all the time something is missing compared with WinZip. It's only a simple field which can improve the overview in the file list. It is the Path-Field which is in WinZip, so I get a complete overview over all files and I don't must hop into all the folders. Greetings Mike

item.title: #747 Select files by time and archive bit
item.detail: For backup purposes, apart from manage the archive bit (mentioned in other feature request) it would be ideal to be able to specify the date of the files to archive. Like in the info-zip program with the parameter '-t'. For example, I want only to archive the files created or modified after 2008-01-01 (-t20080101), or before (-T20080101). This feature and to be able to select files by archive bit and to be able to change this bit is a must to use 7-Zip for backup purposes. Thanks

item.title: #115 Resource usage
item.detail: Would it be possible to decrease the amount of system memory 7-zip uses when compressing? If it's at all possible to use the harddrive a little more, but whatever is most efficient. The reason I ask is that 7-zip used 80MB of memory compressing a 20MB tar file. I checked that using the task manager (performance tab). I'm not familiar with the 7-zip algorithm for compression, but it should be capable to work with small parts at a time.

item.title: #269 Displaying "estimated file size" while compressing
item.detail: It would be cool for the archiver to try to estimate the resulting file size from the very beginning. Now we know we can have some time approximation, but when it takes hours to complete it would be nice to know at least approximately what the total size would be since it would allow adjusting Dictionary/Word size etc. Shouldn't be hard to implement at all, and would work well on evenly laid large files.

item.title: #837 Ignore Hidden Files When Compressing
item.detail: When archiving directories that are under source control, I often want to exclude the source control directories before sending the source to someone. At the moment I have two methods to do this 1) Copy the directory somewhere else and use Windows Explorer to find the CVS or SVN directories, delete everything that comes up in the search results, compress the folder with 7zip then delete the copied directory. 2) Use the command line to exclude files like Entries, Entries.Old, CVS, SVN etc Since it can be done via the command line, would it not be possible to have an option in the GUI that says "Exclude Hidden Files" or "Exclude source control directories" or something?

item.title: #600 use "move" instead of "copy" from temp folder
item.detail: Can you change behaviour of 7-zip to use "move" instead of "copy" when 7-zip unzips the files. Issue is with single HDD systems and big files, this will speed up things significantly. WinRAR does it right now.

item.title: #745 Icon in context menu
item.detail: Please add icon in context menu

item.title: #297 Self extraction file on split archive
item.detail: It will be great if i can split the file and create a self extraction executable to combine the split archive just like winzip and winrar. This is to solve the problem of the recipient not needing to use 7zip to combine the archive

item.title: #120 "Drag and Drop" Support
item.detail: 7-Zip is needing a drag and drop support. I'm missing a lot the feature of extraction by just dragging a file over a folder, like other file archivers have.

item.title: #861 Handling of TGZ / TAR.GZ files
item.detail: In other archiver tools, such as WinRAR, extracting files from .tgz or .tar.gz files is done easily in one step. With 7-Zip, I have to first extract the tar file, and then perform a second extraction of the extracted .tar file. My suggestion is that for .tgz and .tar.gz extensions, and 7-Zip provide a second option in the Windows context-menu to automatically extract the .tar contained within the archive. This would save a lot of hassle, and also make it easier to convince users to adopt 7-Zip.

item.title: #310 Builder and Delphi Component
item.detail: It's interesting encapsulate SDK in Borland Component Package, for C++Builder (ver. 6 is full ANSI C) and Delphi (specialy C# version for Delphi2005.net). A great potential to popularizate. Call the emulators programmers, it is best than old zip! Go 7 go!

item.title: #381 RightClick on zipped file, show preview
item.detail: If I click the right button on zipped file, the windows show the follow picture preview in zipped file.

item.title: #176 Default associations
item.detail: Sorry about my duplicate post of the previous RFE. As a former WinZip user, it took me quite a while to find the "hidden" option to automatically associate ZIP and other extensions to 7-ZIP file manager. Therefore I would suggest to do either of the following: [a] automatically associate .7Z and .ZIP to the program during the installation [b] after installation, automatically launch the File Manager and open the Options window (with .7Z and .ZIP flagged by default, preferrably) [c] if you cannot do it after installation, maybe you could open the Options window whenever File Manager is first launched. The disadvantage of option [c] is that a stupid user like myself, wouldn't even think about launching the File Manager by himself, because we WinZip users just don't expect to have to do this (and frankly, I rather didn't open the WinZip GUI anyway). I realise that it's just a stupid thing, but it's usually this type of thing that make a program easy and intuitive to work with. It's the difference between having to read all the options in the right click menu (and find "Open Archive" in it) or just double clicking, like most of us love to do... Thanks for hearing me out! Regards, Robert

item.title: #106 Absolute Paths for command line
item.detail: Hallo, it would be great if there would be the possibility to use absolute pahts for the command line version. Today only relatvive paths can be used. Marc

item.title: #974 Add "Compress to <Archive>_<Date>.7z" to context menu
item.detail: Adding the ability to quickly compress a file or folder to a zip file with a built in date of today would be a great and simple productivity tool. The context menu would be something like "Compress to _.7z" where would evaluate to something that sorts well like YYYY-MM-DD. e.g. "WebApplication1_2010-08-19.7z" This would make it fun to quickly make a backup before you start messing with some files. Anthony

item.title: #645 single click extract -all (no 'select all's)
item.detail: When a zip/7z file is _open_ in 7zip file manager, users are forced to 'select all' before clicking extract. A single 'extract' or 'extract all' button should extract the entire archive without any selection (or irrespective of the selection).

item.title: #609 Callable Programming API
item.detail: It would be nice if the tool included some callable programming API - for example, if it could be "registered" as/like a DLL or Active-X object. Tracker.5.tlr@xoxy.net

item.title: #1019 Option for default compression method and level
item.detail: Right now using shell extension "right click" "add to xxxx.7z" will always use LZMA at "normal" level. In many cases, I would like to use LZMA2 for its better compress speed with multi-core CPU. To use LZMA2, I have to use "Add to archive" and then navigate through all the options. But if I change the compression level, it will reset the compression method back to LZMA. It would be a lot easier for user if there is an option to set the default compression method and level for "right click, add to xxxxx,7z".

item.title: #878 Window reusing
item.detail: Why isn't included an option to reuse the windows (Win XP)? son that only one instance of 7-zip is open at a time. This option is available in every other archiving program. I think it's very useful to avoid excesive window-cluttering on desktop. It's one of the few little details that separates 7-zip from perfection (imho). Thanks for any response.

item.title: #368 Ctrl+A Selects All Files
item.detail: Ctrl+A Selects All Files in most Windows applications. Please add this standard. Thank you for a wonderful product.

item.title: #343 RFE--Please support .tgz extension
item.detail: As I suggested here: _id=1267656&forum_id=45797 Just treat it exactly the same as a .gz and gunzip it.

item.title: #999 extraction log for 7za.exe and 7zsd.sfx
item.detail: Actually extraction log for 7za.exe console tool and 7zsd.sfx module would be great, useful and powerful feature. I'm founder and developer of USETOOLS project about absolute alternative advantages with usage of free and open source software running on x86 hardware. It is non-commercial project. We created script-based installation enviroment based on modified sfx module and command line versions of 7-zip for cooking fast and clean high-compressed installers. They were tested a lot during long period of time about several years on plenty of hardware configurations. So we decided to use that methode as the best one for packages installation and rejected nsis, msi, etc. It was not so easy but we implemented all missing functions via cmd but it take too much time for support of such packages... Now i'm reconstructing all basic project enviroment on the go and packaging system is one of fundamental ones for the project. Thus EXTRACTION LOG COULD BE ONE THE BEST FEATURES. The log file format should be plain (maybe as one of possible variants controlled via cmd line parameters) i.e. package.log: DIR0 DIR0\file1.txt DIR0\file1.ini DIR0\file1.exe DIR1\file1.txt readme.txt ... Thank you for developing and supporting one of the best software applications for Windows platform.

item.title: #457 Installshield CAB file support
item.detail: It would be great if 7-zip supported the Installshield CAB format of compression. Their are currently few ZIP utilities that support this format, mostly command line utilities such as synce ( ).

item.title: #1013 Add Symantec GHOST Image Files
item.detail: Please add Symantec GHOST-files support. GHO and GHS. You already support WIM and VHD so it should be easy to add GHO and GHS support. Thanks!

item.title: #1082 16px icon
item.detail: Super utility sw, although I am regulary experiencing an issue with "regular" users. They just simply don't recognize file is associated with 7zip because file association icon (16px) is too "modest"... not "popuping" up enough. Should use more contrast or something. Due to this users often install some other zip tool. Icon, at least 16px one, should stand-out more. Br, Peter

item.detail: I wonder why seven zip hasn't approached computer manufactures about being able to work out a way that they could help making extract thev recovery files instead of running the recovery application that are provided by the manufactures as it would be quicker and easier to get your files out of the .fbw recovered files extracted out of there as it would be alot easier

item.detail: I have come to realize the Blu-Ray ISO uses UDF 2.5 and at the present moment, 7-zip cannot open UDF 2.5 Iso files. Also, from what I understand, Blu-Ray ISOs can also be UDF 2.6, so perhaps support for that can be added as well? Thanks, -Neil

item.title: #238 JAR file support
item.detail: I'd love 7zip to have JAR file support, which would make it my only archive manager. Thanks for this great program, sf.n@nekko.de

item.title: #633 more powerful multilanguage support
item.detail: I know that 7-zip now can run at any language OS.But there is a common case that 7-zip can not proccess correctly. Image that I create a archive on a japanese OS with some japanese file names. Then I send it to a man who is using a chinese OS,then he uncompress the archive,what he will get? He will uncompress successfully but all of the file names are not correct. Now I plan to add some context menu by myself and using AppLocale to invoke 7-zip to process the archives which are from another language OS or which I plan to send to a different language OS user. Yes,I think I can solve the promblem now,but I have to study the startup arguments of 7-zip,it's so terrible... I think perhaps we can add a function that user can add a different 7-zip context menu with custmized language which they offen have to use,so that user can proccess the archives with a different language from using OS.

item.title: #391 Customizable Hotkeys
item.detail: It would be nice to be able to assign my own hotkeys to various operations. At the very least, including a hotkey for adding files to an archive would be helpful.

item.title: #356 MPQ
item.detail: Will 7-Zip have the ability to open MPQ Archives? if so it would be great.

item.title: #619 support for blu-ray disc sizes
item.detail: blu-ray drives come in 25GB, 50GB and will soon come out in 100GB size. support for split/combine for this would be a nice feature.

item.title: #235 Support for DAT
item.detail: Hello! 7zip is really a good program! Only one format is missing: Because there are people mailing me attachements in a dat-archive, I still have to have WinZip or WinRAR installed. Please add DAT-Files to the package.

item.title: #137 Uninstall
item.detail: I can't find the uninstall file, why not leave the file or a shortcut to it in the 7-zip folder after installing

item.title: #179 Comments
item.detail: I want an option where you can add comments.

item.title: #653 new -u (Update options) switch to just include file headers
item.detail: Backup can be made with... \Apps\7-ZipPortable\App\7-Zip\7z -y %passwordcmd% -w%temp% -x!\Backup\ -x!\Transfer\ -ms=off -r u "%subdest%\%prefix%ref.7z" -u- -up0q0r2x2z1w2!"%subdest%\%prefix%refnew.7z" -up0q3r2x2z0w2!"%subdest%\%prefix%new.7z" "%subsource%" ...where "%prefix%refnew.7z" contains current full backup version of the archive, and where "%prefix%new.7z" contains the changes of the archive since last backup. The problem is that "%prefix%refnew.7z" becomes very large and is updated for each backup performed. This takes a lot of time. Wouldn't it be great to have an option just to store the directory structure, i.e. exclude the file data? (action 4 and 5 are new) Description 0 Ignore file (don't create item in new archive for this file) 1 Copy file (copy from old archive to new) 2 Compress (compress file from disk to new archive) 3 Create Anti-item (item that will delete file or directory during extracting). This feature is supported only in 7z format. 4. copy file header from the old archive to new one (exclude file data). 5. store the new file header from disk into the archive (exclude file data).

item.title: #686 Compress to ISO image
item.detail: Add support for compressing a directory tree or a user defined set of files to an ISO image, either a CD iso or a DVD iso image. cdrtools is open source and could be used as a back end for this purpose. InfraRecorder is a front end currently using CDRtools (both open source).

item.title: #188 spanned archives
item.detail: the ability to create spanned archives (automatic (fill media) or custom size (like 700 MB)) and to extract from those types of archives as well

item.title: #1032 Adding .zip extension instead of replacing the old extension
item.detail: I would like to compress several files with an extra extension ".zip". For example if I have a file named "mytext.doc" then I would like to archive it as "mytext.doc.zip" and not "mytext.zip". Unfortunately the right click menu offers only the latter one. There should be a configuration in 7zip how zip compression should work: - replace extension with ".zip" - adding extension ".zip" Thanks, Csongor

item.title: #402 Shutdown on complete
item.detail: Please provide support so that the computer shuts down when the program finishes it's current task as in winRAR

item.title: #685 ISO, please.
item.detail: ISO, please.

item.title: #767 Context menu on a 32-bit file manager on x64
item.detail: There needs to be a 32 bit context menu handler for the x64 version of 7zip. A 32-bit file manager such as Total Commander does not show 7zip on the context menu, when running on Windows x64. Note that WinRAR has done exactly this, and it works nicely.

item.title: #1098 --no-dir-entries
item.detail: Please add an option to not create directory entries when compressing, similar to zip's "-D" or "--no-dir-entries". This is needed to create APK files for Android, which do not usually have dir entries. from -D --no-dir-entries Do not create entries in the zip archive for directories. Directory entries are created by default so that their attributes can be saved in the zip archive.

item.title: #442 Extremely long file name support
item.detail: Windows has the ability to support file names up to 65k in length, however, it does not seem that 7-zip works well with files over 250 in length. We have a large number of files that (including paths) are over 500 in length -- any chance 7-zip could be changed to use the \\?\ path format when working with files and therefore support the full 65k length?

item.title: #564 display file size in byte
item.detail: in version 4.4.2, if the file is larger than 9KB, then it shows XXX K. but sometimes i just need to see if the compressed file is a copy of another file in other folders by FILE SIZE. It is the easiest way. So I hope that there would be an option for this. Thanks for your hard working! bluekurk@gmail.com

item.title: #617 FILE TYPE column is essential
item.detail: but where is it? Please add FILE TYPE so we can sort on it, thanks Steve Burke

item.title: #160 Create Folders from Copy To
item.detail: From within an archive, choosing File > Copy To & then entering a folder name that doesn't exist, but you want created should create the folder. It should work just like right clicking on an archive & choosing Extract files. From there you can have a new folder created if it doesn't exist. Instead you get an error message "can not open output file D:\Program Files\New".

item.title: #826 Multivolume self-extractor
item.detail: Would it be possible to allow creating multiple volume self-extractors? This way one could create a self-extractor that could be burned to multiple CDs.

item.title: #956 Extract all files in a dir when previewing
item.detail: It would be a very useful modification (at least as an option) if previewing of one file would cause extraction of all the other files from the same folder to the temp location. This would be invaluable in many situations, like for example: - when previewing an exe file - often an exe may look for additional required files in its directory (like dlls, config files etc.), - when previewing an html file - otherwise it's shown without accompanying stylesheet and images, - when previewing an image - then the image viewer could be conveniently used to browse through all the pictures. This feature could be triggered e.g. by some additional (configurable) key pressed when opening a file.

item.title: #156 error recovery, drag&drop, better background
item.detail: just wanted to put in a few votes for what I think would be most useful to implement on 7-zip. Error recovery is probably the most difficult but I would really like to be able to recover most of a 7-zip from a scratched cd and be able to rebuild the archive like rar supports. Drag and drop would be VERY convenient for updating/compressing/decompressing archives. The background seems to be a foreground process set on a timer, it doesn't use all the resources when the computer is idle and it doesn't give up all resources when the computer is fully engaged (it'd also be cool if it went into the system tray like winrar does). Finally, if there was any way to speed up renaming within a 7- zip/deleting from a 7-zip it would save me time. I think this project is great and I now use .7z whenever possible. Thanks for a great product!

item.title: #317 Default compression Format
item.detail: Would it be possible to set an option where specify the default format for compression? I mean, if I want to compress my files to .rar format instead of 7z, i have to choose the option 'add to file...' and then specify the .rar (or any other) format from the combo box (i can't use the direct option 'compress to "file.7z") If i want to work always with .rar files, it would be pretty and practical to be possible to fix that setting to the default compression format. Thank you very much boys, good job!!

item.title: #448 create SFX from available archives
item.detail: an option to create SFX from available archives would be great

item.title: #1090 option to prioritize input speed
item.detail: Please consider implementing an option where compression level is dynamic such that the input data is processed as fast as can be read. When the option is used, the bottleneck would not be compression but the input speed. This would be useful for large files containing large amounts of easily compressible data. The goal is for the compression to complete as fast (or close to) as it would be to just reading the input; with the resulting output being smaller if input contained alot of easily compressible data.

item.title: #602 Extract all if select none

item.detail: "Extract to" favorites/preset locations should be possible. Manually navigating to often used folders is so low-fi.

item.title: #288 Full row select in filemanager
item.detail: It's annoying (at least in 4.10) than you have to select files by clicking the name, you cant click anywhere on the line.

item.title: #377 more extensive drag and drop functionality please
item.detail: I like 7zip a lot overall and useful. Howeer, I would like more explorer functionality integrated into 7z manager - drag and drop from the manager into other application to open a file - drag and drop from explorer to 7z fiel maanger to add an item to the archive - right click on an item in 7Zip file manager to pop up explorer type of menu item Call me and my friends spoiled if you will, but I hope you like the above suggestions to make the product even more user friendly and apprecated. I am not sure what syamtnec Ghost use for compression, they seem to compress very well and faster then 7z on P4 2.8Mhz I don't know if it is because it is not operating as XP but soem sort of PC DOS or they have better compression engine. Or I don't know to make 7z run faster (version 4.2x).

item.title: #540 Multi output
item.detail: I would like a multi output option for example from a set of subdirectories \1001 \1002 \1003 \1004 the command line version (or the Gui one) should create 1001.7z 1002.7z 1003.7z 1004.7z each archive having precicely the content of the directory with the same name perhaps simply with a new wildcard for the archive name like this 7z a # -r *

item.title: #804 GZip in a single step
item.detail: Allow adding to a .tar.gz archive in a single step. Currently, it requires a single file only in order to add to a GZip file. Since .tar.gz is very common, it would be worthwhile for an option to do both at the same time.

item.title: #389 2 features request
item.detail: 1 - Add SFX options so we can select destination folder, silent mode installation .. and so on 2 - Capability to select many files with mouse (CTRL-A works fine but ...) Many thanks for this great job Regards (Sorry for my english if mistakes, i'm french user ... a fault confessed is half redressed ;o)

item.title: #525 Adding files by date
item.detail: Perhaps I am missing something very obvious but I don't see any date option in 7-Zip. This is a basic for any compression utility and good old PKZIP 2.5 allows you to add files either older or newer than a specified date. Example - pkzip logdata d:\logs\*.* -t takes all files newer than or equal to a date (default=today)

item.title: #130 Support for Mac Formats
item.detail: Support for ".hqx" and ".sit" formats would really be helpful for companies that must send files back and forth to publishing or graphics design people. Right now, the only program to my knowledge that handles ".sit" is Stuffit Expander (which is an awful program to use). WinZip currently handles the ".hqx" files. Greg Miller gmiller@k-eis.com

item.title: #456 File Manager as Explorer Replacement
item.detail: It would be great to use the file manager as an Explorer replacement/alternative as well. As many users I set Explorer to not showing extensions and hidden files for evereyday user's work. However I need a second filemanager showing hidden files and extensions as well. 7-Zip filemanager is slim and fast, ideal for this task, but does not support normal file operation. To use it as a (second) fully featured filemanager non-compressing file move/copy would be required. Could be implemented as a context menue choice. Thanks!

item.title: #663 untar and ungzip in one step
item.detail: When selecting "extract here" in the contextual menu on a foo.tar.gz file, the file should be both gunzipped and untarred, not just gunzipped, leaving the tar file.

item.title: #903 [explorer context menu] cascading config and icon
item.detail: a) support both cascading and toplevel context menu entries and have a config to decide which item is shown at all an then where tortoiseSVN does this to some degree b) plz add icons to the context menu and key shortcuts

item.title: #1070 Need Hotkey for Test
item.detail: 7-Zip (the GUI) does not seem to have a key for the test function. This can be frustratingly inconvenient and very easy to fix. I look forward to it in the next beta. Thanks.

item.title: #620 support DVD ISO file format
item.detail: DVD ISO file format seems to be the same as ISO, only bigger. I do have some examples where 7-Zip can't read all files inside DVD image, i.e. only 24Mb instead of 1,8Gb

item.title: #945 Open command prompt (console) from file manager
item.detail: It would be great if it was possible to open a command prompt with currently viewed directory. Something equal to cmd.exe -> cd /d "", accessible from menu/toolbar/hotkey.

item.title: #411 Command prompt in the file manager
item.detail: 7-Zip File Manager is an excellent tool, but it's missing something that just about every orthodox file manager should have - the command prompt. This simple (from the user's perspective) feature would extend the file manager's capabilities expotentially, and would certainly make it far more useful to me. Hell, I would write it myself if I knew C++ or anything about how the plugin interface works.

item.title: #586 Encode and Decode Unix-to-Unix files
item.detail: Email files (.msg .eml) attachments include uuencoded files. If you try to view/decode("extract") those files you need and uudecoder (or the same mail client/platform). It would be nice to have these feature. P.D. Thanks for your work, i love 7-zip

item.title: #980 multipart file extraction with unknown order
item.detail: It would be nice to get the information which volume a file form a multi-part archive is. I now came across an archive, where ALL parts had the SAME filename (let's say: archive.rar [48 MB], then archive.rar [48 MB], then archive.rar [48 MB], and finally archive.rar [17 MB]), of course all in differnt folders! With 7zip I could not sort out the real order of the files (in fact it were more than just 4 ;-)), because opening each file separately did not give me any information which volume ist should be... So I had to go back to WinRAR, which just give the information neede to rename and finally unpack the archive properly! See attached screenshot!

item.title: #360 Command line passwords
item.detail: Typing passwords interactively (i.e. without -p arg) in command-line operations shows a completely readable password. Instead, it should be better to display a sequence of * in place of real characters. CGP gianpiero.canciani@poste.it

item.title: #321 Media spanning
item.detail: I tried to use 7-Zip to replace my copy of Winzip, but had to go back to Winzip because 7-Zip doesn't seem to have a way to span multiple media (floppy disk, CD, etc)

item.detail: Add support for Inno Setup compression, It use file header id "zlb" "ZLIBID: TCompID = 'zlb'#26;" <- from Struct.pas Link to source code:

item.title: #977 7-zip icons
item.detail: Change the default icons in 7-zip please

item.title: #295 Z archive support...
item.detail: Do not know much about archive file formats.... I found this format when downloading some compressed Unix help files (I'm Windows user). Ends with ,Z (capital). 7-zip wont decompress it, but it should be easy to implement support for it since it is Unix compression format (I guess). Thanks, bye

item.title: #177 Make it more like WinRAR!
item.detail: I am sorry to say this, but WinRAR is (IMO) the most "polished" compressor. So learn from them. 7-Zip compression kicks its ass (unless your talking about speed, or jpg's or bmp's). Add some of its features (comments, SFX features, splitting + recovery volumes etc) Taemun
